author: juliane
title: Empower thru Project Based Learning
description: There are not enough project based learning (PBL) formats available for DEVs to become blockchain DEVs and deliver on the work ahead.

f6_assessments.q0: Yes, the proposal addresses the challenge setting by creating educational material it helps onboard new developers and gives existing developers an ability to learn Plutud smart contract effectively.  It also shows new developers that educational content is available. Project-based learning approach is an effective Hands-On learning experience that focuses on learning by doing. The project will run for six months and should have proved successful, then James will come back for additional funding. The Plutus smart contract language is a functional language that is quite different to all the other languages that programmers are used to. Having practical examples helps devs learn and practice algorithms that they might recognize but have difficulty implementing with this new language. I think the proposal is well align with the challenge setting
f6_assessments.q1: The Proposal is the co-founder of the Gimbalabs team. He provides links to his LinkedIn profile and has relevant experience in creating teaching material. James has been a high-school maths and computer science teacher for the last 11 years, and he has published two math curriculums that are still in use today. While teaching, he tries to use new tools to facilitate deep learning. James will design and deliver the courses.  the budget is set at $36,000 which will cover a salary for James of $6,000 per month for 6 months this is a reasonable salary for a developer on Cardano. Should the program be a success, James will come back for additional funding in future funding rounds. The Proposal is divided into two sections the operational part which will hold weekly playground meetings, prepare the meetings, documentation and collect feedback. The Innovation stage is composed of self-study and skill up for the participants; design and development of more project-based learning formats and experiment with new designs of project-based learning. This format has been tried and tested with the Gimbalabs team. There will not be any new software developed there for no discussions I made about languages architecture.  James highlights the risk that there might be a lack of project-based learning expertise should something happen to him; however, two to three developers are already being trained to become the next teachers. James also highlights the risk that there might not be enough students to participate in the Project-based learning program; however, experience has shown that the previous iterations of this program by Gimbalabs have shown a lot of interest. A growing Cardano ecosystem will be conducive to more participants in the type of program.  I would be interested in joining the program when it launches. I would have liked James to elaborate a little more on how this proposal differs from the project-based learning programs that Gimbalabs run and why the submission is made by him rather than the team as a whole.  I have no doubts that James will be able to deliver on this proposal
f6_assessments.q2: Yes, the roadmap is clearly stated; it will run over six months, and the educational content will be prepared and delivered by James. The KPIs are well-defined and will be measured weekly.  They focus on the number of playgrounds and project-based learning held, the number of participants, and the number of new project-based learning pilots launched. The success of this project will be to empower more and more developers to build on Cardano; create an environment that is safe for innovation, and creates success stories that become businesses. The deliverable is straightforward to audit as these are public courses that anyone can attend and view the recording afterward.

f6_assessments.q0:
One of the key pillars of the Developer ecosystem challenge setting is the creation and maintenance of developer support structures.

Education is key to the support network of any developer community, and the Cardano developer community is no exception. This is especially true because it not only is a relatively new developer community, but it also operates under a totally different paradigm in the blockchain space given it’s eUTxo model and Haskell based programming. 

Because of this, relatively few developers are familiar with the tools, methods and best practices. 

As such, it is especially important for those who are familiar to share the knowledge they have accumulated if they are willing and able to do so. Over the course of the last almost two years, James and the Gimbalabs team have proven that they are more than capable of taking on this challenge.

The proposal is asking for funding to enable the continuation of the Project Based Learning program for the 6 month (July - December 2022).

I haven't been a part of the Gimbalabs Project Based Learning workshops myself, but the people I have come across who have, are praising them. For the work they do and the methods they are developing.

Maintaining this core education infrastructure is key to the future developer adoption of the Cardano stack, something I think we can all agree is fundamental to the general adoption of our blockchain. By funding this work it is my assessment that we are only paying for the planting of a seed, but our whole ecosystem has a chance to be impacted greatly by it, and we might end up enjoying a small forest.

My assessment is based on the over 5 years of experience I have in managing mobile app studios and the fact that I have been involved in the Cardano developer community since March 2021. For the last year, I have also been actively project-managing Cardano developers.
f6_assessments.q1:
The project plan and roadmap makes a lot of sense and is very simple to follow. It is actually a continuation of the PBL framework the Gimbalabs team already has in place. 

The detailed budget breakdown is only a line, but that is actually not a problem in the case of this proposal as the allocation of funds is very simple: six-month compensation for a master educator. 

The project is part of the Gimbalabs initiative and is spearheaded by James Dunseith the founder and core driver of the PBL project. He is a master educator with a vast experience in teaching. James’ LinkedIn page is also provided in the proposal and it backs -up and ads to the data provided in the proposal.

Despite the fact that the new question related to work on previously funded proposals is answered as “Yes”, no additional details are provided in the main feasibility section as is now requested by the proposal submission form. However, I will not be lowering my rating because of this, as the question has been introduced in Fund 9 and the proposers may have not fully understood what is being requested of them, but, I do suggest the team include full answers on future submissions, especially as they have indicated that they will be returning to Catalyst to seek additional funds in the future.

Even though it’s not provided in the proposal, the information about past funded Gimbalabs proposals and current fund 9 proposals is available at https://www.lidonation.com/en/project-catalyst/group/gimbalabs . This tool definitely helps the community see the volume of work that needs to be managed. My assessment is that the volume of work is more than manageable for the Gimbalabs team, especially considering that they are already implementing the project that is in the scope of this proposal and the requested funds are simply for continuing the project.
f6_assessments.q2:
From what I’ve been able to observe during the last year and a half, Gimbalabs have been very transparent with their activities and this project is no exception. The KPIs are straightforward and easy to follow as they focus on the metrics around the educational content that will be provided.

The definitions of success for this project are very well presented and they do a very good job of explaining the importance of this project by themselves, as they lay out all the benefits that a Cardano developer interacting with the Project Based Learning course would stand to gain.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is a project based learning proposal. The idea is to train developers to become proficient and be able to work and develop real world cardano decentralized applications. This is done through the project based learning approach .. meaning you work on actual project to gain your skills, which as a developer I can verify is the preffered and proven way to learn something new.
The impact of this proposal is sure to be great and has already been empirically proven to be so. The growth between version 1 and version 3 is amazing and is sure to be even greater further down the line when more people and trainers get involved. I would love to take part of this experience and learn something new because I would enjoy transfering my skills to the cardano ecosystem as I'm sure many developers are.
Sharing knowledge is a noble goal and I do appreciate the hard work and effort put into craeting the video content and all the documentation. I also love the open source learning concept, and the combination between a github project to work on and a youtube tutorial is becomming more and more poppular so I suggest to the proposers to consider it if they haven't already.
This proposal would give the skills to devs, in a short time, to become a self sustained business if they so choose and the opportunities in the cardano ecosystem are endless as I see it. Overall this is one impactfull proposal that matches the challenge settings, helping developers in their journey and helping them better educate themselves and help out business idea of others or develop their own.
f6_assessments.q1:
James Dunseith (co-founder Gimbalabs) is has all the credentials to teach people and has already proven to be capable. I managed to verify all the listed skills with the ones in the linked profile and with a bit of googling managed to find out more about the people that have passed his lessons and all seem to be appreciative and happy. In that train of thought I'd recommend to James and the proposers to collect success stories in the form of a short video made by a developer, because there's no better marketing than regular people speaking out for the benefits of the program and it's always nice to connect a face to a story, hence the videos.
The program will span 5 months till late december, which is a good timeframe based on my experience if a little too short, but with the right motivation it's farr from impossible. There will be weekly playground meetings that will help developers get to know the program and each other better and make colaboration easier.
There's a sensible plan for implementation and all the relevant details will be documented as mentioned several times. Testing frameworks will also be a topic which is overlooked in other such projects which is a sin if you ask me. A tested application is a reliable one.
The budget seems reasonable, considering James does this only and is entirely focussed on it. The hourly rate is a bit low if you ask me, but that makes the value / cost ratio even more appealing for voting it in, which I encourage all voters to do. This is a negligible amount compared to the value it will bring long term. 
Overall a feasible solution to an importan problem. No devs means no ecosystem growth because it's a digital world so we need digital gurus to be generated. Good luck to James in his endeavour.

I love the definition of success where his planning on passing the torch down the line and expanding the PBL programes to more than one. This is a worthy goal of a true educator.

f6_assessments.q0:
Empowerment through Project-Based Learning" was written by James Dunseith. This proposal not only appealed to me for the effective application of the PBL learning method but also expressed my admiration for James Dunseith from a man. Math teacher honored as both Math for America and BetterLesson Master Teacher and co-founder of Gimbalabs.
PBL is understood as Project-Based - Learning. It is a student-centered learning method that directs students to acquire knowledge and skills through embarking on a specific project to solve a problem. Students will go through a process of discovery and discovery to solve a challenging project that requires thinking. This is an active, effective learning method that helps students directly apply what they have learned.
With this powerful learning method, James Dunseith applies it to introduce developers to the Cardano ecosystem by providing the open-source learning opportunities needed to upskill developers. Become a Blockchain developer.
By piloting the "Plutus" Project-Based Learning (PPBL) project series, developers gain experience with Plutus. Other projects are also being planned and are tested, We can see project schedule information here: https://www.gimbalabs.com/gimbalgrid/6
"Product is"Gimbalabs Playground": This is a weekly meeting format where community members and (not yet the community) can share ideas, present a project, and receive feedback from many colleagues.
This is also the tool and also the way to attract developers from outside the community to participate in the Catalyst project. The proposal aims to build networks by fostering relationships with individuals and groups in the Catalyst community.
This project has been successfully tested and applied from July 2020 to the present. I realize this is a long-term, sustainable project that James is aiming for. From the analysis points, it shows that the proposal is completely consistent with the challenge criteria of Developer Ecosystem set forth."

The proposal outlines possible risks, but those risks are small and can be overcome.

I completely agree with this proposal.
